content.description:
The Next Green Revolution
Half a century ago disaster loomed just as ominously (as today). Speaking about global hunger in 1959, one economist said, “At best the world outlook for the decades ahead is grave; at worst it is frightening.”
Before those visions could come to pass, the green revolution transformed global agriculture, especially wheat and rice. [S]elective breeding created a dwarf variety of wheat that put most of its energy into edible kernels rather than long, inedible stems. The result: more grain per acre. Similar work in the Philippines dramatically improved the productivity of the grain that feeds nearly half the world. From the 1960s through the 1990s, yields of rice and wheat in Asia doubled.
To keep doing that between now and 2050, we’ll need another green revolution. There are two competing visions of how it will happen. One is high-tech, with a heavy emphasis on continuing breeding better crops, but with modern genetic techniques. “The next green revolution will supercharge the tools of the old one.” Scientists, he argues, can now identify and manipulate a huge variety of plant genes, for traits like disease resistance and drought tolerance. That’s going to make farming more productive and resilient.
The signature technology of this approach—and the one that has brought both success and controversy to Monsanto—is genetically modified, or <math alttext="G M" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, crops. First released in the 1990s, they’ve been adopted by <math alttext="28" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>28</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> countries and planted on <math alttext="11" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent of the world’s arable land, including half the cropland in the <math alttext="U S" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>U.S.</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> About <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent of the corn, cotton, and soybeans grown in the <math alttext="U S" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>U.S.</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are genetically modified. Americans have been eating <math alttext="G M" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> products for nearly two decades. But in Europe and much of Africa, debates over the safety and environmental effects of <math alttext="G M" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> crops have largely blocked their use.
A recent study by the <math alttext="U S" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>U.S.</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Department of Agriculture found that pesticide use on corn crops has dropped <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>90</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent since the introduction of <math alttext="B t" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> corn, which contains genes from the bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis that help it ward off corn borers and other pests. Reports from China indicate that harmful aphids have decreased—and ladybugs and other beneficial insects have increased—in provinces where <math alttext="G M" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GM</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cotton has been planted.
content.question: Which of the following is an assumption made by the author regarding the use of genetically modified crops?

choices.label: Eventually, pests will become resistant to the <math alttext="B t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Bt</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> gene, and pesticide use will increase in the near future.
The amount of arable land will remain relatively constant, and the growing human population will have enough food if more crops can be harvested from the same amount of land.
Farmers in more-developed countries will grow fewer genetically modified foods in the near future because they are not cost effective.
Current agricultural practices are effective enough to feed the global population, but improvements in technology will help crops such as cotton and tobacco.

content.answer: The amount of arable land will remain relatively constant, and the growing human population will have enough food if more crops can be harvested from the same amount of land.
